PARALLON March 05, 2020 First Level Appeal CareSource Medicaid Via Certified Mail Attn: Appeals PO BOX 2008 DAYTON, OH 45401- 2008 Re: Patient: AYAD AZIZ Subscriber / Policy: 10439059400 Claim: 2003803AXK00 Acct No.: 101730890 Patient DOB: 09/17/1950 Facility: OSCEOLA REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTER Date(s) of Service: 12/10/2019 - 12/17/2019 Total Charges: $309,151.81 Appeal Amount: $19,723.49 Dear Appeals Director: We are in receipt of the denial of above member's claim based upon your internal coding guidelines. The Facility disagrees that this claim was incorrectly coded. Accordingly, the Facility submits its Reconsideration Request for a coding review of the above member's denied service of the claim stating PDX 572.22XA is invalid. We are requesting reconsideration of the denial per the attached documentation. Coding is correct per ICD10 official coding guidelines. Specifically, the medical record supports the use of PDX 572.22XA. The patient was a 69-year-old M that presented to the ED via EMS with c/o weakness, left hip pain, and left leg pain s/p ground-level fall. His PMH was significant for HLD, HTN, DM and CVA (April 2019) with residual left-sided weakness. VS: VP 174/89, P 76, R 18, T 98.0, 02 sat 98% on 2L NC, and pain Intensity 10/10. Abnormal labs included potassium 3.2, chloride 110, magnesium 1.5, Hgb 12.2, and Hct 36.8. Knee XR negative for fracture and/or dislocation. Pelvis XR notable for displaced left proximal femoral fracture. EMS administered Fentanyl en route but the patient was still in extreme pain, so he was given IV Morphine in the ED. The patient was admitted with a subtrochanteric femur fracture and ortho was consulted. On 12/10/19, he underwent an ORIF of the fracture I C GIC 040117

PARALLON' without any documented complications. The patient was monitored closely postop and participated in PT/OT. By 12/17/19, he was deemed stable for discharge to a SNF. The PDX is correct, as well as all coding and DRG 480. Section II. Selection of Principal Diagnosis The circumstances of inpatient admtsuon always govern the selection of principal diagnosis The principal diagnosis it defined na the Umform Hospital Discharge Data Set (UHDDS) as -that condition established after study to be chiefly responsible for occasioning the admission of the patient to the hospital for care " The UHDDS &funny= are used by hospitals to report Inpatient data elements to a standardized manner. These data elements and then definitions an be found in the July 31. 19S S. Federal Register (Vol 50. No. I47). pp 31035-40 Sure that time the application of the MODS definitions has been expanded to include all non- outpatient centrists (acute care. than tam, long term are and psychiatric hospitals, home health agencies, rehab facilities, nursing homes, etc) The UHDDS definitions also apply to hospice services levels of care) In determining principal diagnosis, coding coin canons in the ICD-10-CM. the Tabular Last and Alphabetic Index take prw.eikawe over these official coding gum:Wales ass Seen,, LA., Comvntrons for Ms 1CD-10-CM) ICD-10-01 Metal thuctel)nrs as Coding rod Reporting I'S 2011 Additionally, we request a review of the medical records for approval of the services provided. As the attached medical record demonstrates, the member has S72.22XA and the treating physician deemed it necessary for the member to undergo treatment for this service, as medically necessary for continued care of the member. The Facility provides care at the direction of the attending physician and, in turn, requests reimbursement for services rendered to your member. We expect a prompt payment of this claim. Should benefits remain denied, please provide a detailed explanation of why the charges do not qualify for the coding utilized by the Facility's billing department including any explanation of how payment was calculated, the criteria used for any denial, and any coding edits that were utilized. If you have any questions, please contact Cheryl Smith at (904) 688-2139. Thank you for your immediate attention to this appeal. Sincerely, Cap-Lid Iv Wag frtzr RN , Carolyn Wagner, RN Clinical Appeals Specialist 1.C.GIC 040117

P PARALLON ERISA — Adverse Determination In the event of an adverse benefit determination, whether in whole or in part, of a claim governed by ERISA, please provide a copy of the Summary Plan Description, along with copies of any and all service contracts with administrators, third-party administrators, fiduciaries, and all parties in interest as defined by ERISA, that have any involvement whatsoever with the review and/or audit and/or pricing with regard to decisions involving the payment and/or denial, in whole or in part, of benefits for health care services and claims. In addition, please provide notification in a manner to be understood by the claimant: (1) the specific reason(s) for the determination, (2) reference to the specific plan provisions on which the determination is based, (3) a description of any additional material or information necessary for the claimant to perfect the claim and an explanation of why such information / material is necessary, (4) a description of the plan's review procedures and time limits applicable to such procedures including a statement of the right to bring a civil action under section S02(a) of the Act following an adverse benefit determination on review. In the case of an adverse benefit determination by a group health plan or a plan providing disability benefits, you are hereby requested to provide free of charge, a copy of, or statement that, the internal rule, guideline, protocol, or other similar criterion that was relied upon in making the adverse determination and if the adverse benefit determination is based on a medical necessity or experimental treatment or similar exclusion or limit You are hereby requested to provide free of charge, an explanation of the scientific or clinical judgment for the determination, applying the terms of the plan to the claimant's medical circumstances, together with the name(s), of the physician(s) or health care professional(s), credentials, training, and experience in the field of medicine involved in the medical judgment in this matter. In the case of an adverse benefit determination by a group health plan concerning a claim involving urgent care, a description of the expedited review process applicable to such claims. See 29 CFR 2560.503-1 ENCLOSURES: Entire Medical Record UB-04 Remittance advice Assignment of Benefits ADDITIONAL ENCLOSURES: 1 C GIC 040117

AYAD, AZIZ OSCEOLA REGIONAL MEDICAL 101 /30890 ER CENTER 12110/2019 Timothy Generic for Julien MD DOB 09/17/1950 69 y MR# N000880775 Conditions of Admission and Consent for Outpatient Care In this document, "Patient" means the person receiving treatment. "Patient Representative" means any person acting on behalf of the Patient and signing as the Patient's representative. Use of the word "I," "you," "your" or "me" may in context include both the Patient and the Patient Representative. With respect to financial obligations "I" or "me" may also, depending on the context, mean financial guarantor "Guarantor". "Provider" means the hospital and may include healthcare professionals on the hospital's staff and/or hospital-based physicians, which include but are not limited to: Emergency Department Physicians, Pathologists, Radiologists, Anesthesiologists, Hospitalists, certain other licensed independent practitioners and any authorized agents, contractors, affiliates, successors or assignees acting on their behalf. 1. Legal Relationship between Hospital and Physicians and Advanced Practice Professionals. I understand and acknowledge that the physicians and advanced practice professionals providing services to me in the hospital are independent contractors and not agents or employees of the hospital. "Advanced Practice Professionals" include, but are not limited to, my treating physicians/ surgeons, radiologists, pathologists, cardiologists, emergency physicians, anesthesiologists, contract physicians, hospital-based physicians, physician assistants, registered nurses, advanced practice registered nurses, certified nurse midwives, certified registered nurse anesthetists, clinical psychologists, clinical nurse specialists, doctors of nursing practice, radiology assistants, and anesthesiology assistants. Independent physicians and Advanced Practice Professionals are responsible for their own actions and the hospital shall not be liable for the acts or omissions of any such independent physicians and/or Advanced Practice Professionals. 2. Consent to Treatment. I consent to the procedures that may be performed during this hospitalization or during an outpatient episode of care, including, but not limited to, emergency treatment or services, and which may include laboratory procedures, x-ray examination, diagnostic procedures, medical, nursing or surgical treatment or procedures, anesthesia, or hospital services rendered as ordered by the Provider. I consent to allowing residents and other individuals enrolled in a healthcare professional education program as part of their training in health care education to participate in the delivery of my medical care and treatment or be observers while I receive medical care and treatment at the Hospital, and that they will be supervised by instructors and/or hospital staff. I further consent to the hospital conducting blood-borne infectious disease testing, including but not limited to, testing for hepatitis, Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome ("AIDS"), and Human Immunodeficiency Virus ("HIV") , if a Provider orders such tests or if ordered by protocol. I understand that the potential side effects and complications of this testing are generally minor and are comparable to the routine collection of blood specimens, including discomfort from the needle stick and/or slight burning, bleeding or soreness at the puncture site. The results of this test will become part of my confidential medical record. 3. Consent to Treatment Using Telemedicine. I consent to treatment involving the use of electronic communications ("Telemedicine") to enable health care providers at different locations to share my individual patient medical information for diagnosis, therapy, follow-up, and/or education purposes. I consent to forwarding my information to a third party as needed to receive Telemedicine services, and I understand that existing confidentiality protections apply. I acknowledge that while Telemedicine can Patient:AYAD, AZIZ MRN:N000880775 Encounter:N00101730890 Page 1 of 10

AYAD, AZIZ OSCEOLA REGIONAL MEDICAL 101730890 ER CENTER 12/10/2019 Timothy Generic for Julien MD DOB: 09/17/1950 69 y MR#: N000880775 be used to provide improved access to care, as with any medical procedure, there are potential risks and no results can be guaranteed or assured. These risks include, but are not limited to: technical problems with the information transmission or equipment failures that could result in lost information or delays in treatment. I understand that I have a right to withhold or withdraw my consent to the use of Telemedicine in the course of my care at any time, without affecting my right to future treatment and without risking the loss or withdrawal of any program benefit to which I would otherwise be entitled. 4. Use of Biological Samples. During your care at the facility, biological samples (such as blood and tissue samples) might be collected from you for purposes of your care. Sometimes, after your visit there might be excess or leftover biological samples no longer needed for your care. These samples are usually discarded. However, sometimes these samples might be used for research within our hospitals and occasionally made available to researchers at external groups such as universities, private companies, advocacy groups, and government agencies. The research can help answer questions about the causes of diseases, how to prevent them, or even how to treat them. Please note that for this kind of research, (i) there might be no practical way to inform you about the details or results of the research (even if it involves genetic research), (ii) generally, no results on tests performed on your samples during the research can be returned to you or entered into your health record, (iii) it is not likely that you will directly benefit from the research, and (iv) there are no plans to compensate or recognize you for use of your samples or any discoveries made during the research. When these samples are used in this manner, your privacy is safeguarded consistent with applicable federal and state privacy laws. 5. Consent to Medication Not Yet FDA Approved and/or Medication Prepared/Repackaged by Outsourcing or Compounding Pharmacy. As part of the services provided, you may be treated with a medication that has not received FDA approval. You may also receive a medication that has been prepared or repackaged by an outsourcing facility or compounding pharmacy. Certain medications for which there are no alternatives or which your physician recommends may be necessary for potentially life-saving treatment. 6. Consent to Product Patient Assistance Programs Limited Power of Attorney ("LPOA"). The Provider may be able to get free replacement or reimbursement for the cost of your drugs or medical products from the companies that make them through a patient assistance program sponsored by the companies that make your drugs or medical products and through charity foundations. If the hospital obtains replacement or reimbursement of cost of your drug or medical product from the manufacturer through such programs, the charge for the product or drug will be removed from your bill. Patient assistance programs require you to sign an application form in order for the hospital to obtain replacement or credits of certain drugs administered or devices implanted to qualifying patients. This LPOA allows the Provider and its claims processor to complete and sign your patient assistance program applications for you for so long as this program may be available to you. I hereby appoint hospital and/or its claims processor, my attorney-in-fact for the sole and exclusive purpose of signing patient assistance program application forms on my behalf, so that hospital may attempt to obtain replacement or credits of certain drugs administered or devices implanted from the companies that make them. However, Patient and Guarantor understand that if Patient does not qualify under the hospital's charity care policy or other applicable policy, Patient or Guarantor is not relieved of his/her obligation to pay for these services. In this event any payment required from the Patient or Guarantor will be determined by the terms of the governmental program or private health insurance plan. If the Patient is uninsured and not covered by a governmental program, the Patient may be eligible to have his or her account discounted or forgiven under the hospital's uninsured discount or charity care programs in effect at the time of treatment. I understand that I may request information about these programs from the hospital. I also understand that, as a courtesy to me, the hospital may bill an insurance company offering coverage, but may not be obligated to do so. Regardless, I agree that, except where prohibited by law, the financial responsibility for the services rendered belongs to me, the Patient or Guarantor. I agree to pay for services that are not covered and covered charges not paid in full by insurance coverage including, but not limited to, coinsurance, deductibles, non-covered benefits due to policy limits or policy exclusions, or failure to comply with insurance plan requirements. 9. Professional services rendered by independent contractors and Advanced Practice Professionals are not part of the hospital bill. I understand that physicians and other Advanced Practice Professionals may be called upon to provide care or services to me or on my behalf, but that I may not actually see, or be examined by all physicians or other Advanced Practice Professionals participating in my care; for example, I may not see physicians, including but not limited to, my treating physicians/ surgeons, radiologists, pathologists, cardiologists, emergency physicians, anesthesiologists, staff physicians, contract physicians, physician assistants and other Advanced Practice Professionals including those providing radiology, pathology, EKG interpretation, anesthesiology services or telemedicine. I understand that, in most instances, there will be a separate charge for professional services rendered by these providers and that I will receive a bill for these professional services that is separate from the bill for hospital services. 10. Third Party Collection. I acknowledge that the Providers may utilize the services of a third party Business Associate or affiliated entity as an extended business office ("EBO Servicer" ) for medical account billing and servicing. During the time that the medical account is being serviced by the EBO Servicer, the account shall not be considered delinquent, past due or in default, and shall not be reported to a credit bureau or subject to collection legal proceedings. When the EBO Servicer's efforts to obtain payment have been exhausted due to a number of factors (for e.g., Patient or Guarantor's failure to pay or make a payment arrangement after insurance adjustments and payments have been credited, and/or the insurer's denial of claim(s) or benefits is received), the EBO Servicer will send a final notice letter which will include the date that the medical account may be returned from the EBO Servicer to the Provider. Head/Eyes: atraumatic, normocephalic, NL conjunctiva/sclera Cardiovascular: normal heart sounds, pulses all extremities Respiratory/Chest: atraumatic, clear to auscultation Abdomen: soft, non-tender, no guarding, no rebound, no distention Extremities: dry, moves all, LLE compartments soft, NVI distally, some swelling, wiggles toes Neuro/CNS: alert, oriented X 3, normal gait, normal speech Discharge Instructions Diet: diabetic (pureed solids, all liquids ok), Encourage high protein Activity: as tolerated, TTVVB LLE Wound/dressing care: change dressing prn Prescriptions: on chart Rx drug database reviewed: yes Follow-up Appointments Attending Physician: Attending Physician: Skattum,Andrew C DO Special instructions: Discharge Instructions: Pain Management Take pain medications only as prescribed Do not double up or take more than prescribed amounts Do not take additional Tylenol (acetaminophen) with your pain medicine it it contains acetaminophen. faking too much acetaminophen can be harmful to your liver or cause liver failure. It is acceptable to take additional over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAI Ds) like Ibuprofen, Naprosyn, Alleve, Motrin, etc. as directed on the bottle unless you have a history of cardiac disease, renal failure, ulcer or allergy. Do not drive, drink alcohol, or operate heavy machinery while taking narcotic pain medications such as Vicodin, Norco, Lorcet, Lortab, Codeine, Percocet, Oxycontin, Oxycodone, Morphine, Dilaudid, etc. Also, do not sign legal documents while taking these medications. Narcotic pain pills can be constipating. Make sure you drink plenty of fluids and eat fiber. If you find that you are constipated, over-the-counter stool softeners or laxatives such as Colace, Ducolax, Correctol, Senokot, Ex-Lax, Fleets, Milk of Magnesia, lactulose, or mineral oil may be beneficial. Take as directed on the package. Enemas and suppositories may also Page 6 of 8 Patient:AYAD, AZIZ MRN:N000880775 Encounter:N00101730890 Page 6 of 8

Patient: AYAD,AZIZ Unit#:N000880778 Date: 12/17/19 Acct#:N00101730890 be helpful. If you had sigmoid colon or rectal surgery, please do not take any rectal temperatures or rectal medications, including enemas or suppositories. What to Look For: Please call your physician's office or return to the emergency department (ED) for: Fevers greater than 101° F (38.3° C). Nausea and vomiting that is severe and doesn't go away. Severe pain not relieved by the prescribed pain medicine or worsening after your discharge from the hospital. Severe diarrhea or constipation If you have a cut or a wound, you should watch for any bright red bleeding from your wound. If you have a cut or wound, you should call if there is redness around your wound or drainage from your wound that smells bad or looks like pus. If you have a splint, it should firmly hold the injured bone or joint. If it is too tight, you may get swelling, numbness, color changes or increased pain. For any other symptoms that you might find abnormal or distressing, please call your physician's office for clarification or return to emergency department (ED). In the case of an emergency, call 911. Call your physicians the day of discharge for follow-up appointments. Patient reports gait instability at baseline since his CVA. Pt and family report that was he was getting out of bed to use the restroom and fell down on his right side d/t gait instability. Pt denies head truama or LOC. Per family, patient immediately shouted for help. Pt was given 125 of fentantyl w/ EMS. In the ED pt was found to have left sided proximal femur fx. Pt was given 8 of morphine prior to my assessment and still complains of 8/10 pain. Patient is at proximal left hip and radiates to anterior and lateral aspects of knee. Pt reports pins and needle sensation over the lateral aspect of thigh and calf. Patient requesting pain medications at this time. OSCEOLA REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTER CONSENT FOR BLOOD and/or BLOOD PRODUCTS sod/or HUMAN DERIVED PRODUCTS The following form is used by Osceola Regional Medical Center for informed consent for the use of Blood and/or Blood Products and/or Human Derived Products. It is the need of your physician to know your wishes on the receiving of these products, to treat a medical condition or transfuse during a surgical procedure or in en emergency situation. Blood/Blood products have not been ordered, but in the event of an emergency: Dr. has ordered blood end/or blood products for Anna Blood loss/Bleeding Other (Explain) It has been explained to me that these products include: Leukoreduced Red Blood Cells. Leukoreduced Single Donor Platelets, Plasma, Cryoprecipitate, Rh Immune Globulin, Albumin, Imminioglobulins and Cloning Factors 7, 8, and 9. What steps are taken to make sure that the blood patients receive is safe? There are many safeguards on our national blood supply to ensure safe blood for patients. Pint. blood is donated by volunteer donors. Before giving blood, donors must answer questions about their health and risk factors for disease and only a person who appears in good health can give blood. Blood from each accepted donor goes through extensive testing. In addition to tests for blood type, screening tests are run for evidence of infection with hepatitis, HIV (the virus that causes AIDS), HTLV virus (which may cause blood and nerve disease), West Nile Virus, and syphilis, a sexually transmitted disease. Finally, a blood sample from the donated unit of blood is tested against blood from the patient who will receive it to ensure that the blood is compatible. RISKS -What are the risks of receiving blood? If a blood nansfinion is needed during a surgical procedure or other medical treatment, the risks of not receiving blood far outweigh the risks of transfusion. But like any other drug or medical treatment there are risks and potential side effects. Sonic patients may have a reaction to transfusion causing mild symptoms such as fever. chills, or hives, which typically require little or no treatment. The transmission of disease occurs very rarely, and seldom threatens life. Approximate risks of contracting HIV (one in 1.900.000). Hepatitis C (HCV ) one in 1.600,000), Hepatitis B (HBV) one in 63.000) and Hepatitis A (HAY) one in 1,000,000. No matter how carefully blood is drawn, processed, and stored, complete elimination of microbes and viruses is impossible. Extreme risks, however unlikely, may lead to death. BENEFITS-Why would any doctor recommend that I receive blood? You may need to receive blood in order to stabilize your condition or to save your life. If tests show that you have dangerously low levels of blood, your doctor may order a transfusion to replace what is mining. The amount of blood given to you is a decision your physician will make based on your particular needs. ALTERNATIVES-Do I have choices other Than receiving blood from the community blood supply? Yes. you may have other choices. Autologous blood transfusion refers to procedures m which you may serve as your own blood donor In preoperative autologous donation, your blood may be collected and stored before a scheduled surgery where blood use is expected. In addition, blood lost during surgery can sometimes be saved and returned to you (Cell Saver). In other situations you may be able to select the donors of your blood (usually a friend or relative) and receive a directed donation. The use of growth factors and hemostatic agents, surgical devices and techniques to minimize blood loss as well es volume expanders are important alternatives to the ate of blood I (we) have been given the opportunity to ask questions about my condition, treatment, risks of non-treatment, the procedure to be used, and the nsks, benefits, alternatives and potential complications to my (our) satisfaction. ANESTHESIA DISCLOSURE & CONSENT I (We) understand that anesthesia involves additional risKs and hazards but I (We) request the use of anesthetics for the relief and protection from pain during the planned and necessary additional procedures. I ( We) understand that certain complications may result from the use of any anesthetic including but not limited to respiratory problems, drug reaction, paralysis, peripheral nerve injury resulting from positioning, brain damage or even death from causes known or unknown. Other risks and hazards, which may result from the use of general anesthetics, range from but are not limited to minor discomfort such as a sore throat to lasting injury to vocal cords, teeth or eyes. Chipped, cracked or tooth extractions are complications of anesthesia and your anesthesia provider cannot assume liability for teeth. I (We) understand that other risks and hazards resulting from spinal, epidural or other regional anesthetics include but are not limited to headache, chronic pain, transient or permanent nerve damage, bleeding, and infection. I (We) understand the above risks are not totally inclusive of all known anesthetic risks and I (We) will be given the opportunity to discuss further known and unknown risks of anesthesia If I (We) desire. I (We) have been given an opportunity to ask questions about my condition, treatment, risks of nontreatment, the procedure to be used, and the risks, benefits and alternatives, and I (We) believe that I (We) have suffident information to give this informed consent. OSCEOLA REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTER 700 WEST OAK STREET KISSIMMEE, FL 34741 PATIENT: AYAD,AZIZ MEDICAL RECORD $:N000880775 ACCOUNT #: N00101730890 ROOM/BED: N.A209-1 ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: Dr. Block,Ernest F MD DICTATED BY: Dr. Menanotte,Thomas MD DATE OF ADMISSION: 12/10/19 LOCATION: N.NTICU DATE OF DISCHARGE: Operative Report ACCOUNT NUMBER: 101730890 DATE OF SERVICE: 12/10/2019 SURGEON: Thomas Mezzanotte, MD ASSISTANTS: Rebecca Hanna, PA. She was assisting in positioning, draping, soft tissue retraction, fracture stabilization, closure and bandaging in order to help facilitate a safer more effective case. PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIAN: SANDRA M SNYDER PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: Left hip subtrochanteric femur fracture with intertrochanteric extension. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: Left hip subtrochanteric femur fracture with intertrochanteric extension. PROCEDURE: Left hip open reduction and internal fixation with plates and screws of the left subtrochanteric femur fracture with intertrochanteric extension. ANESTHESIA: ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: SPECIMENS REMOVED: INDICATION FOR PROCEDURE: A 69-year-old gentleman with a history of CVA and peripheral vascular disease, who fell. He has a left subtrochanteric femur fracture with intertrochanteric extension. Risks and benefits were discussed with the patient and family. Risks include, not limited to, bleeding, infection, nerve damage, failure of the operation to relieve the symptoms. He is at high risk for cardiopulmonary complications because of his age and comorbid conditions. DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The patient was taken to main operating room. Preoperative antibiotics and general anesthesia were administered. He was placed on the fracture table. Gentle in-line traction was used. Fluoroscopic views were obtained. It was ascertained that this would not be amenable to intramedullary nailing because of the intertrochanteric extension and greater trochanteric split, so at this point, the patient was then placed in the right PATIENT NAME: AYAD,AZIZ ACCOUNT t: N00101730890 Patient:AYAD, AZIZ MRN:N000880775 Encounter:N00101730890 Page 1 of 2

lateral decubitus position using a bean bag holder. Left lower extremity was prepped and draped in usual sterile fashion for orthopedic procedure. An 18 cm incision was made from the tip of the greater trochanteric region past the midshaft of the femur. The fascia was incised. We then did careful dissection along the greater trochanteric region and then distally. Excellent hemostasis was obtained. The greater trochanteric extension did extend in the entire intertrochanteric region and through the greater trochanteric region and then spiral distally to about the mid shaft of the femur. we did dissect anterior and posteriorly exposing the fracture and then distally. The clamps were then used to hold the fracture in anatomic position. Three lag screws were placed from anterior to posterior holding the fracture in anatomic position. A synthes greater trochanteric plate with a long extension then was used. K-wires were placed into the femoral neck. They were over-drilled and then two 6.5 mm screws were placed distally. Drill holes were drilled and filled distal to the fracture site with 4.5 mm screws. Fluoroscopy confirmed good placement of the hardware, good reduction of the fracture. The wound was irrigated. The fascia was closed interrupted monofilament. The skin was closed with interrupted monofilament staples. The patient was then taken to the postanesthesia care unit. Anesthesiologist noted that he was having some PVCs on his EKG monitoring. They were going to monitor him more fully in the recovery room. I gave him a unit of blood and possibly send him to the ICU when stable. A positive troponin risk stratifies a patient to an increased likelihood of 'schema or infarction, is not diagnostic and requires clinical correlation. A radiation dose optimization technique was used for this scan. FINDINGS: There is mild generalized cerebral atrophy. There is no intracranial hemorrhage. There are low-attenuation changes in the bilateral periventricular white matter, nonspecific but most consistent with chronic small vessel ischemic disease. The remaining brain parenchyma is normal in attenuation. There is no evidence of a mass, mass effect, or midline shift. The ventricles and basal cisterns are normal. There are no abnormal intra or extra-axial fluid collections. There is a small craniectomy defect at the vertex. There is near-total opacification of the right sphenoid sinus with periosteal thickening. The visualized paranasal sinuses are otherwise clear. The visualized mastoid air cells are clear. IMPRESSION: Mild generalized cerebral atrophy. Chronic small vessel ischemic disease. Small craniectomy defect at the vertex. Please correlate clinically. No acute intracranial abnormality. Pi*s.14A1*)14*0Ai#014iiIi PCP: Undefined Provider Special Instructions: FOLLOW UP WITH PCP IN REHAB Attending Physician: Skattum,Andrew C DO Attending Physician Phone: (407)520-3947 Followup Tineframe: In 2-3 weeks special Instructions: Discharge Instructions: Pain Management Take pain medications only as prescribed Do not double up or take more than prescribed amounts Do not take additional Tylenol (acetaminophen) with your pain medicine if it contains acetaminophen. Taking too much acetaminophen can be harmful to your liver or cause liver failure. It is acceptable to take additional over-the-counter non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like Ibuprofen, Naprosyn, Alleve, Motrin, etc. as directed on the bottle unless you have a history of cardiac disease, renal failure, ulcer or allergy. Do not drive, drink alcohol, or operate heavy machinery while taking narcotic pain medications such as Vicodin, Norco, Lorcet, Lortab, Codeine, Percocet, oxycontin, Oxycodone, Morphine, Dilaudid, etc. Also, do not sign legal documents while taking these medications. Narcotic pain pills can be constipating. Make sure you drink plenty of fluids and eat fiber. If you find that you are constipated, over-the-counter stool softeners or laxatives such as solace, Ducolax, Correctol, Senokot, Ex-Lax, Fleets, Milk of Magnesia, lactulose, or mineral oil may be beneficial. Take as directed on the package. Enemas and suppositories may also be helpful. If you had sigmoid colon or rectal surgery, please do not take any rectal temperatures or rectal medications, including enemas or suppositories. What to Look For: Please call your physician's office or return to the emergency department (ED) for: Fevers greater than 101 F (38.3 C). Nausea and vomiting that is severe and doesn't go away. Severe pain not relieved by the prescribed pain medicine or worsening after your discharge from the hospital. Severe diarrhea or constipation If you have a cut or a wound, you should watch for any bright red bleeding from your wound. If you have a cut or wound, you should call if there is redness around your wound or drainage from your wound that smells bad or looks like pus. If you have a splint, it should firmly hold the injured bone or joint. If it is too tight, you may get swelling, numbness, color changes or increased pain. For any other symptoms that you might find abnormal or distressing, please call your physician's office for clarification or return to emergency department (ED). In the case of an emergency, call 911. Patient:AYAD, AZIZ MRN:N000880775 Encounter:N00101730890 Page 3 of 5
